facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 7 of 1962

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 7 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated October 14, 1957 of the Punjab High Court in R.F.A. No. 219 of 1950

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated October 14, 1957 of the Punjab High Court in R.F.A. No. 219 of 1950.

facts.text: Plaintiff instituted the suit in the court of Sub-Judge, First Class, Batala

anchor.surface_text: He had instituted the suit in the court of Sub-Judge, First Class, Batala,

facts.text: Sub-Judge, First Class, Batala dismissed the suit in its entirety

anchor.surface_text: who dismissed it in its entirety.

facts.text: High Court of Punjab upheld the dismissal of the plaintiff's claim for specific performance

anchor.surface_text: Upon appeal the High Court of Punjab, while upholding the dismissal of the plaintiffs claim for specific performance,

facts.text: High Court modified the decree to order defendants to repay earnest money to plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: modified the decree of the trial court in regard to one matter. By that modification the High Court ordered the defendants to repay to the plaintiff the earnest money

facts.text: Pindidas died during the pendency of the appeal before the High Court

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that Pindidas died during the pendency of the appeal before the High Court

facts.text: Legal representatives of Pindidas were substituted in his place

anchor.surface_text: and his legal representatives were, therefore, substituted in his place.

facts.text: Plaintiff came to Supreme Court by certificate under Art. 133 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the dismissal of his claim for specific performance the plaintiff has come up to this Court by a certificate granted by the High Court, under Art. 133

facts.text: Plaintiff owned 79/120th share in Khasra Nos. 494, 495, 496, 497, 1800/501, 1801/501 and 529 shown in the zamabandi of 1943-43, situate at Mauza Faizpur of Batala

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff owned 79/120th share in Kasra Nos. 494, 495, 496, 497, 1800/501, 1801/501 and 529 shown in the zamabandi of 1943-43, situate at Mauza Faizpur of Batala.

facts.text: On October 1, 1943 plaintiff purchased 23/120th share in the land from Devisahai

anchor.surface_text: On October 1, 1943 he purchased 23/120th share in this land belonging to one Devisahai.

facts.text: Plaintiff became owner of 17/20th share in the land

anchor.surface_text: He thus became owner of 17/20th share in this land.

facts.text: Remaining 3/20th share belonged to joint Hindu family managed by Pindidas with members Haveliram Khemchand and Satyapal

anchor.surface_text: The remaining 3/20th share belongs to the joint Hindu family of which Pindidas was the Manager and his brother Haveliram Khemchand and Satyapal were the members.

facts.text: Plaintiff paid Rs. 175 per marla for the land purchased from Devisahai

anchor.surface_text: According to the plaintiff he paid Rs. 175 per marla for the land which he purchased from Devisahai.

facts.text: Contract for sale of 3/20th share entered into on October 1, 1945 with Pindidas and Rs. 100 paid as earnest money

anchor.surface_text: The contract in this regard was entered into on October 1, 1945 with Pindidas and Rs. 100 were paid to him as earnest money.

facts.text: Pindidas as manager failed to execute the sale deed

anchor.surface_text: As the manager of the family failed to execute the sale deed in his favour,

facts.text: Plaintiff made Pindidas and his brothers defendants to the suit

anchor.surface_text: the plaintiff instituted the suit and made Pindidas and his brothers defendants thereto.

facts.text: Pindidas admitted entering into contract of sale on October 1, 1945 and receiving Rs. 100 earnest money

anchor.surface_text: Pindidas admitted having entered into a contract of sale of some land to the plaintiff on October 1, 1945 and of having received Rs. 100 as earnest money.

facts.text: Pindidas claimed the contract pertained not to the land in suit but to another piece of land

anchor.surface_text: According to him, however, that contract pertained not to the land in suit but to another piece of land.

facts.text: Defendants 2 to 4 denied the existence of any contract

anchor.surface_text: The defendants 2 to 4 denied the existence of any contract

facts.text: Courts below found Pindidas entered into contract for sale of 3/20th share of family land in suit and received Rs. 100 earnest

anchor.surface_text: The courts below have found in the plaintiffs favour that Pindidas did enter into a contract with him for the sale of 3/20th share of the family land in suit and received Rs. 100 as earnest money.

facts.text: Courts below held the contract was not binding on the family because no necessity for sale and not for benefit of family

anchor.surface_text: But they held that the contract was not binding on the family because there was no necessity for the sale and the contract was not for the benefit of the family.

facts.text: Defendants are persons in affluent circumstances and there was no necessity for the sale

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed before us by Mr. N. C. Chatterjee for the plaintiff that the defendants are persons in affluent circumstances and that there was no necessity for the sale.

facts.text: All brothers of Pindidas were adults when the contract was entered into

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us all the brothers of Pindidas were adults when the contract was entered into.

facts.text: There is no allegation in the plaint that the sale was contemplated by considerations of prudence or difficulty in managing the property

anchor.surface_text: In the present case there is unfortunately nothing in the plaint to suggest that Pindidas agreed to sell the property because he found it difficult to manage it or because he found that the family was incurring loss by retaining the property.
Art. 133 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Jagatnarain v. Mathura Das 1 . That is a decision of the Full Bench of that High Court in which the meaning and implication of the term benefit of the estate is used with reference to transfers made by a Manager of a joint Hindu family was considered. The learned Judges examined a large number of decisions, including that in Hanooman Persaud Pandey v. Babooee Munraj Koonweree 2  Sahu Ram Chandra v. Bhup Singh 3  and Palaniappa Chetty v. Sreemath Daivasikamony Pandra Sannadhi 4  and held that transactions justifiable on the principle of benefit to the estate are not limited to those which are of a defensive nature.

precedents.cited_proposition: transactions justifiable on the principle of benefit to the estate are not limited to those which are of a defensive nature. According to the High Court if the transaction is such as a prudent owner of property would, in the light of circumstances which were within his knowledge at that time, have entered into
precedents.cited_holding: the adult managers of the family found it very inconvenient and to the prejudice of the familys interests to retain property, 18 or 19 miles away from Bijnor [...] that there is nothing to indicate that the transaction would not have reached a profitable conclusion

precedents.citation: Hanooman Persaud Pandey v. Babooee Munraj Koonweree 2

anchor.surface_text: Hanooman Persaud Pandey v. Babooee Munraj Koonweree 2  Sahu Ram Chandra v. Bhup Singh 3  and Palaniappa Chetty v. Sreemath Daivasikamony Pandra Sannadhi 4  and held that transactions justifiable on the principle of benefit to the estate are not limited to those which are of a defensive nature. According to the High Court if the transaction is such as a prudent owner of property would, in the light of circumstances which were within his knowledge at that time, have entered into, though the degree of prudence required from the manager would be a little greater than that expected of a sole owner of property.

precedents.case_name: Hanooman Persaud Pandey v. Babooee Munraj Koonweree
precedents.cited_proposition: decisions examined in Jagatnarain v. Mathura Das on the meaning of benefit of the estate for transfers by Manager of joint Hindu family

precedents.citation: Sahu Ram Chandra v. Bhup Singh 3

anchor.surface_text: Sahu Ram Chandra v. Bhup Singh 3  and Palaniappa Chetty v. Sreemath Daivasikamony Pandra Sannadhi 4  and held that transactions justifiable on the principle of benefit to the estate are not limited to those which are of a defensive nature. According to the High Court if the transaction is such as a prudent owner of property would, in the light of circumstances which were within his knowledge at that time, have entered into, though the degree of prudence required from the manager would be a little greater than that expected of a sole owner of property. The facts of that case as found by the High Court were the adult managers of the family found it very inconvenient

precedents.case_name: Sahu Ram Chandra v. Bhup Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: decisions examined in Jagatnarain v. Mathura Das on the meaning of benefit of the estate for transfers by Manager of joint Hindu family

precedents.citation: Palaniappa Chetty v. Sreemath Daivasikamony Pandra Sannadhi 4

anchor.surface_text: Palaniappa Chetty v. Sreemath Daivasikamony Pandra Sannadhi 4  and held that transactions justifiable on the principle of benefit to the estate are not limited to those which are of a defensive nature. According to the High Court if the transaction is such as a prudent owner of property would, in the light of circumstances which were within his knowledge at that time, have entered into, though the degree of prudence required from the manager would be a little greater than that expected of a sole owner of property. The facts of that case as found by the High Court were the adult managers of the family found it very inconvenient and to the prejudice of the familys interests to retain property, 18 or 19 miles away from Bijnor, to the management of which neither of them could possibly give proper attention, that they considered it to the advantage of the estate to sell that property and purchase other property more accessible with the proceeds, that they did in fact sell that property on very advantageous terms, that there is nothing to indicate that the transaction would not have reached a profitable conclusion . . .  P. 979 . I.L.R. 50 All. 969.

precedents.case_name: Palaniappa Chetty v. Sreemath Daivasikamony Pandra Sannadhi
precedents.cited_proposition: decisions examined in Jagatnarain v. Mathura Das on the meaning of benefit of the estate for transfers by Manager of joint Hindu family

precedents.citation: Sital Prasad Singh v. Ajablal Mander 1

anchor.surface_text: Sital Prasad Singh v. Ajablal Mander 1  That was a case in which one of the questions which arose for consideration was the power of a manager to alienate part of the joint family property for the acquisition of new property. In that case also the test applied to the transaction entered into by a manager of a joint Hindu family was held to be the same, that is, whether the transaction was one into which a prudent owner would enter in the ordinary course of management in order to benefit the estate. Following the view taken in the Allahabad case the learned Judges also held that the expression benefit of the estate has a wider meaning than mere compelling necessity and is not limited to transactions of a purely defensive nature.

precedents.case_name: Sital Prasad Singh v. Ajablal Mander
precedents.cited_proposition: power of a manager to alienate part of the joint family property for the acquisition of new property [...] the expression benefit of the estate has a wider meaning than mere compelling necessity and is not limited to transactions of a purely defensive nature [...] the karta [...] must act with prudence, and prudence implies caution as well as foresight and excludes hasty, reckless and arbitrary conduct
precedents.cited_holding: In exceptional circumstances, however, the court will uphold the alienation of a part of the joint family property by a karta for the acquisition of new property as, for example, where all the adult members of the joint family with the knowledge available to them and possessing all the necessary information about the means and requirements of the family are convinced that the proposed purchase of the new property is for the benefit of the estate

precedents.citation: In the matter of A.T. Vasudevan Ors., minors 1

anchor.surface_text: In the matter of A.T. Vasudevan Ors., minors 1 . There a single Judge of the High Court held that the manager of joint Hindu family is competent to alienate joint family property if it is clearly beneficial to the estate even though there is no legal necessity justifying the transaction. This view was expressed while, dealing with an application under cl. 17 of Letters Patent by one Thiruvengada Mudaliar for being appointed guardian of the joint family property belonging to, inter alia, to his five minor sons and for sanction of the sale of that property as being beneficial to the interests of the minor sons.

precedents.case_name: In the matter of A.T. Vasudevan Ors., minors
precedents.cited_proposition: the manager of joint Hindu family is competent to alienate joint family property if it is clearly beneficial to the estate even though there is no legal necessity justifying the transaction

anchor.surface_text: Sellappa v. Suppan 2 . That was a case in which the question which arose for consideration was whether borrowing money on the mortgage of joint family property for the purchase of a house could be held to be binding on the family because the transaction was of benefit to the family. While holding that a transaction to be for the benefit of the family need not be of a defensive character the learned Judges, upon the evidence before them, held that this particular transaction was not established by evidence to be one for the benefit of the family.

precedents.cited_proposition: a transaction to be for the benefit of the family need not be of a defensive character
precedents.cited_holding: this particular transaction was not established by evidence to be one for the benefit of the family
